Author: davidw
Content:
If you're afraid to share something that you considered interesting enough to write, how are you going to promote your company?

I'm not saying spam us every time a few stray neurons fire, but I think this "don't promote your own stuff" idea is some kind of lame artifact from reddit.

Author: bootload
Content:
'... This isn't related to startups at all ...'

funny but in a way it is. It's got to do with brain structure, patterns and ideas ~ http://www.edwdebono.com/debono/berry.htm

The idea is important to startups where imagination and ideas are paramount. The theory is developed by Edward De Bono who's hardly an intellectual flake ~ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_de_Bono

'... unless you learn to escape from the obvious way of looking at things, you will not develop new ideas ...'

So the play on words, puns, cartoons and jokes are just a function of thinking. Beware of humourless hackers. It's a bad sign.

Author: jamongkad
Content: I'd say Ruby(which I'm currently using) but I started out with Perl. And hacking with Perl provided me with a firm foundation. So use Perl :-) cuz it's awesome.

Author: jamongkad
Content: But didn't S3 go down some time ago? How does that say for reliability?

Author: bootload
Content: find a partner who can. then take a quick peek at eric raymonds guide to hacking ~ http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/hacker-howto.html

Author: zaidf
Content:
I am too embarrassed to even mention why I read pg's essays before he got into writing on entrepreneurship. Rest assured, it was still to achieve an entrepreneurial end.

Perhaps someday I'll share with him:)

Author: falsestprophet
Title: Have any of you started a succuessful company because of Mr. Graham's writing or the early reddit entrepreneurial community?

Author: whacked_new
Content:
Python

(edit: late, but I should add why in case you visit again. I find Python to be quite a good cross between the C/C++ based dialects and, say, the newer, and ref a pg article, languages "closer to lisp." Also the syntax reads pretty close to English, and is beautifully formatted. The documentation is plenty too. I'm pretty much all PHP, but I'd recommend Python :) )
